The 'albumins' (formed from Latin: albumen "(egg) white; dried egg
white") are a family of globular proteins, the most common of which is serum
albumin. The albumin family consists of all proteins that are water-soluble, are
moderately soluble in concentrated salt solutions, and experience heat
denaturation. Albumins are commonly found in blood plasma, and are unique from
other blood proteins in that they are not glycosylated. Substances containing
albumins, such as egg white, are called albuminoids.

A number of blood transport proteins are evolutionarily related, including serum
albumin, alpha-fetoprotein, vitamin D-binding protein and afamin.
